issue.title: Increase storage limit for rasterio wheels
issue.body:
We hit the 20 GB this morning. I deleted some 1.0a1 and 1.0a2 wheels to make room. These were from before I learned that I needed to strip libgdal and were twice as big as today's wheels.

Here's the support ticket: https://github.com/pypi/support/issues/3249.

issue.title: np vs numpy in dtypes.py
issue.body:
<!--

WELCOME ABOARD!

Hi and welcome to the Rasterio project. We appreciate bug reports, questions
about documentation, and suggestions for new features. This issue template
isn't intended to ward you off; only to intercept and redirect some particular
categories of reports, and to collect a few important facts that issue reporters
often omit.

The primary forum for questions about installation and usage of Rasterio is 
https://rasterio.groups.io/g/main. The authors and other users will answer 
questions when they have expertise to share and time to explain. Please take the
time to craft a clear question and be patient about responses. Please do not
bring these questions to Rasterio's issue tracker, which we want to reserve for
bug reports and other actionable issues.

Questions about development of Rasterio, brainstorming, requests for comment,
and not-yet-actionable proposals are welcome in the project's developers 
discussion group https://rasterio.groups.io/g/dev. Issues opened in Rasterio's
GitHub repo which haven't been socialized there may be perfunctorily closed.

Please note: Rasterio contains extension modules and is thus susceptible to
C library compatibility issues. If you are reporting an installation or module
import issue, please note that this project only accepts reports about problems
with packages downloaded from the Python Package Index. Conda users should take
issues to one of the following trackers:

- https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues
- https://github.com/conda-forge/rasterio-feedstock

You think you've found a bug? We believe you!
-->

## Expected behavior and actual behavior.

I was not able to import rasterio in my upstream test because dtypes.py imports `numpy as np` but uses `numpy.finfo`. Looks like a merge problem? 

https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/1c003d198655d332f354b13318d80a6cb2026a89/rasterio/dtypes.py#L10

https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/1c003d198655d332f354b13318d80a6cb2026a89/rasterio/dtypes.py#L104-L105

Unrelated, but the module level docstring mentions that numpy is _not_ imported which may need an update? 

https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/1c003d198655d332f354b13318d80a6cb2026a89/rasterio/dtypes.py#L3

The CI run is here: https://github.com/regionmask/regionmask/actions/runs/6581785746/job/17882300901

## Steps to reproduce the problem.

Install rasterio directly from git & try to import. 

#### Environment Information

I don't have this info right now (on my phone). 

## Installation Method

See above.

comment.body: @mathause yes, that commit is broken, but this is not a problem in a released version of rasterio. See https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/1.3.9/rasterio/dtypes.py.

issue.title: Memory leak using rasterio.Env
issue.body:
Hi folks. 

Thank you for your work on this project.

I meet an issue on our project where 

```python
while True:
    with rasterio.Env(**{}):
        pass
```

Generates a memory leak. When one run this code and look for process memory usage, it looks like memory is never released overtime.

By digging a bit more in the code, it looks like the following code is related to the issue:

https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/main/rasterio/env.py#L334

this is where  `__enter__` code generate a new GDAL environment instance

then 

https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/main/rasterio/env.py#L338

is where (I guess)  the memory allocation happens because there no more memory leak when this line is commented.

In my case this happens because I am instanciating this raster io environment into a web (fastapi) route callback where the with statement code is called on every route call.

I cannot do much in my code context in an obvious way with current rasterio.Env api which is usable only using a with statement.

For now I fixed my code with this code which is not clean but does the trick. I never release ressources from the `__exit__` method but this is ok as we are in an ever living web route callback and I cache the `rasterio.Env` instance.

```python
if getattr(self, "gdal_env", None) is None:
    rasterio_env = rasterio.Env(**env)
    self.gdal_env = rasterio_env.__enter__()
```

On the first call, I instanciate the rasterio context and it lives and is cached for all subsequent calls from `self.gdal_env` variable.

Thank you for any help solving this.

issue.title: 1.3.9 release
issue.body: Bug fixes and to patch GDAL against the TIFF compression bug described in https://lists.osgeo.org/pipermail/gdal-dev/2023-October/057810.html. Target date: 2023-10-17.

issue.title: rasterio.dtypes.dtype_ranges seems to be wrong for floating point types
issue.body:
## Expected behavior and actual behavior.

Rasterio maintains a hard-coded mapping between dtype names and min/max values in [`rasterio.dtypes.dtype_ranges`](https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/5e001a08beb747fef0b60b5ccdbf2e5a08da7e05/rasterio/dtypes.py#L104). I would expect all min/max values in this mapping to match their Numpy counterparts, however the floating point types seem to be wrong.

The internet seems to pretty consistently use `3.4028235e+38` as a shorthand for the max `float32` value, however my theory is that this is just an approximation for human interpretation and not intended to be used as an actual maximum value.

Numpy's per-dtype min/max calculations are performed in [`numpy.core.getlimits`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/a0ceb15d79f4f44f1dc853d888889b52b227b1ef/numpy/core/getlimits.py), but my understanding is that Numpy uses IEEE 754 floating point types, and shouldn't really be platform dependent. Specifically, I think this is where Numpy calculates a max value for `float32` as: [`(1 - 2 ** -24) * 2**128)`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/a0ceb15d79f4f44f1dc853d888889b52b227b1ef/numpy/core/getlimits.py#L197)

So, I suspect Rasterio either needs to emulate these calculations, or use the min/max values derived from corresponding Numpy dtypes. A behavior to watch out for: `np.finfo()`'s min/max values are Numpy objects, while `np.info()`'s are not.

## Steps to reproduce the problem.

This snippet:

```python
import numpy as np
import rasterio as rio


dtype = np.float32

rio_min, rio_max = rio.dtypes.dtype_ranges['float32']

finfo = np.finfo(dtype)
np_min = finfo.min.item()
np_max = finfo.max.item()

fmt = '.0f'

print(f"rio min: {rio_min:{fmt}}")
print(f"np min:  {np_min:{fmt}}")
print(f"match:   {rio_min == np_min}")

print(f"rio max: {rio_max:{fmt}}")
print(f"np max:  {np_max:{fmt}}")
print(f"match:   {rio_max == np_max}")
```

illustrates the problem and produces:

```console
rio min: -340282349999999991754788743781432688640
np min:  -340282346638528859811704183484516925440
match:   False
rio max: 340282349999999991754788743781432688640
np max:  340282346638528859811704183484516925440
match:   False
```
